column4: Hardy is still supported, so it is still getting patched.  If you need it early, then look at enabling the hardy-proposed section.
are there any docs for updating glibc with hardy-proposed? since glibc is really critical and can break the system if not done properly, i'm trying to be really careful with this
First, do you mean the AVX bug?  LP #662511
Do you mean the AVX bug?  LP #662511   It might not apply to the older glibc.
http://freshmeat.net/articles/ubuntu-new-gnu-c-library-packages-fix-security-vulnerability
that's the one i'm talking about
i tested it out and it's vulnerable
Double-check that you have hardy-security enabled.
how do i check that?
Look at your /etc/apt/sources.list file.  Or run something like `apt-cache policy glibc`.
unable to locate policy glibc
isn't it called libc6?
libc6: Installed: 2.7-10ubuntu6 Candidate: 2.7-10ubuntu7
That version is current in hardy-updates and blurbed in the vulnerability email, so it seems that you're updated.
i think i'm still on 2.7-10ubuntu6 though
apt-cache poliy libc6 shows Installed: 2.7-10ubuntu6 Candidate: 2.7-10ubuntu7
Right.  Sorry.  You need to do an apt-get upgrade.
APT is telling you that you have the unpatched version installed.
so just apt-get upgrade libc6 ?
Just `apt-get upgrade` unless you have a reason not to do a fully security upgrade.
i don't want to upgrade everything at once.. would just rather do glibc for now ..
does apt-get have a pretend flag? so that i can see what it's going to upgrade
I don't think that upgrade will take a package name.  Try `apt-get install libc6`.
You'll be given an opportunity to refuse if more packages will be installed.
